pullrequest.title: Updating callbacks to consistently define coordinate system

content.raw: Not that the old version was necessarily particularly useful, but doesn't this change the semantics of the callback?  Before it would do a (not necessarily straight) line plot - basically passing the x and y arrays to `ax.plot`.  Now it plots a straight line between two points.
content.html: Not that the old version was necessarily particularly useful, but doesn't this change the semantics of the callback? Before it would do a (not necessarily straight) line plot - basically passing the x and y arrays to ax.plot. Now it plots a straight line between two points.

pullrequest.title: Updating callbacks to consistently define coordinate system

content.raw:
Good point!  I actually struggled for a while on this very problem.  `code_size` was previously defined, so I wanted to leave it in for backwards compatibility, however, it seems odd to me to define the length of arrows that are simply pointing out features in the plot in code units.  The `length` is simply just setting the length in axis units and defaults to 0.03 (1/30th of the axis size), whereas previously you had to set the `code_size` as a required argument.  

I'm happy to get rid of one of them, but I'd just as soon get rid of `code_size` because I don't think it makes sense to require the user to define an arrow length when they just want to point to a feature.  But this breaks backwards compatibility.
content.html:
Good point! I actually struggled for a while on this very problem. code_size was previously defined, so I wanted to leave it in for backwards compatibility, however, it seems odd to me to define the length of arrows that are simply pointing out features in the plot in code units. The length is simply just setting the length in axis units and defaults to 0.03 (1/30th of the axis size), whereas previously you had to set the code_size as a required argument.

I'm happy to get rid of one of them, but I'd just as soon get rid of code_size because I don't think it makes sense to require the user to define an arrow length when they just want to point to a feature. But this breaks backwards compatibility.

content.raw: Good point.  I had not considered this.  You're right that this changes the overall semantics of this function and potentially breaks backwards compatibility.  I had always thought the more useful thing would be to accept two coords as the endpoints of a line and plot that line, but perhaps people want to give it a list of Xs and a list of Ys?  Although then if it is in `data` coords, we should give it a list of Zs too?  Hmm...
content.html: Good point. I had not considered this. You're right that this changes the overall semantics of this function and potentially breaks backwards compatibility. I had always thought the more useful thing would be to accept two coords as the endpoints of a line and plot that line, but perhaps people want to give it a list of Xs and a list of Ys? Although then if it is in data coords, we should give it a list of Zs too? Hmm...

pullrequest.title: Updating callbacks to consistently define coordinate system

content.raw:
If you take a look in the `setup_callbacks` member function of the `PWViewerMPL` class in `plot_window.py`, you'll see that the `LabelCallback` is explicitly disabled.  This callback actually is from the days of `PlotCollection` and has not been used since that code was removed from the codebase.

In other words, this is effectively a new feature and it would be nice if `PhasePlot` got this as well.
content.html:
If you take a look in the setup_callbacks member function of the PWViewerMPL class in plot_window.py, you'll see that the LabelCallback is explicitly disabled. This callback actually is from the days of PlotCollection and has not been used since that code was removed from the codebase.

In other words, this is effectively a new feature and it would be nice if PhasePlot got this as well.

pullrequest.title: Updating callbacks to consistently define coordinate system

content.raw:
Because it persists across all instances of the class.  Consider the following:


```
>>> class MyClass:
...     data = {}
...
>>> a = MyClass()
>>> a.data["what's up?"] = "not much"
>>>
>>> b = MyClass()
>>> print b.data.items()
[("what's up?", 'not much')]
```
content.html:
Because it persists across all instances of the class. Consider the following:

>>> class MyClass:
...     data = {}
...
>>> a = MyClass()
>>> a.data["what's up?"] = "not much"
>>>
>>> b = MyClass()
>>> print b.data.items()
[("what's up?", 'not much')]

content.raw: Rather than copy-pasting the docstrings into the docs, what do you think about linking to the autogenerated API docs?  I worry about the versions of the docstrings in the narrative docs not being updated when the docstrings in the callback code get updated in the future.
content.html: Rather than copy-pasting the docstrings into the docs, what do you think about linking to the autogenerated API docs? I worry about the versions of the docstrings in the narrative docs not being updated when the docstrings in the callback code get updated in the future.

pullrequest.title: Updating callbacks to consistently define coordinate system

content.raw: While I understand your concern of having two places to update in the future, I think in this case each doc location (API vs narrative docs) serves a unique location.  Obviously we need the API docs from the docstrings in the code, so those should stay.  But the narrative docs actually autogenerate the output images (sort of like the cookbook) to let the user know how things are going to look.  We cannot move this functionality inside the api docs without things getting really hard.
content.html: While I understand your concern of having two places to update in the future, I think in this case each doc location (API vs narrative docs) serves a unique location. Obviously we need the API docs from the docstrings in the code, so those should stay. But the narrative docs actually autogenerate the output images (sort of like the cookbook) to let the user know how things are going to look. We cannot move this functionality inside the api docs without things getting really hard.

pullrequest.title: Updating callbacks to consistently define coordinate system

description:
Consistent with the discussion I started on the mailing list a couple weeks ago, this PR makes a universal method for defining/setting the coordinate system associated with plot window callbacks (e.g. annotate_marker()) that is backwards compatible.  

Previously, when you set a coordinate in a callback, it was largely undefined in what coordinate system you were operating--different callbacks operated in different coordinate systems.  Some expected things in MPL axis coordinates, some expected them in 3D data coordinates, some in 2D projected data coordinates, others in the plot coordinate system defined by the axis limits.  Furthermore, the 3D data coordinates would not work for off-axis projections or off-axis slices.

This PR resolves all of those problems and does so with the addition of a data_coord keyword argument to the relevant callback.  data_coord defaults to whatever the previous coordinate system was for that callback to keep with backwards compatibility, even though this makes it less consistent for new users.  perhaps we should set them all to 'data' coordinates for consistency at the expense of slightly breaking backwards compatibility?

The coord_system kwarg is defined as follows:

coord_system : string, optional

    This string defines the coordinate system of the coordinates of pos
    Valid coordinates are:
        "data" -- the 3D dataset coordinates
        "plot" -- the 2D coordinates defined by the actual plot limits
        "axis" -- the MPL axis coordinates: (0,0) is lower left; (1,1) is
                  upper right
        "figure" -- the MPL figure coordinates: (0,0) is lower left, (1,1)
                    is upper right

And here is a demonstration of it in action for on-axis and off-axis projections:

http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/anonymous/d823f670e91b223b946f

In addition, I took this opportunity to clean up the docstrings for the relevant callbacks.  This change also enabled me to combine the annotate_line() and annotate_image_line() callbacks into a single callback, and the annotate_point() and annotate_text() callbacks into a single callback.  

Lastly, I fixed the annotate_axis_label() callback which was broken and did not work.  It now sets the x *or* the y axis label as defined in the callback.

I know this PR still needs updates to the callback docs and to add tests, but I wanted to see what people thought so far.

UPDATE1: Added suggestions by @ngoldbaum .  Deprecated `code_size` kwarg in `annotate_arrow()`.  Edited docstrings.  Changed function name of `sanitize_coord_system()`.  Removed extraneous `AxisLabelCallback` since similar functionality exists as PlotContainer functions and the callback was broken anyway. Removed inactive callbacks from the ignored callback list in `setup_callbacks()`.

UPDATE2: Moved dictionaries containing default keyword arguments from the class level down to the __init__() level so as to avoid repeatability issues of having mutables defined at class level.

UPDATE3: Deprecating (still work, but issue deprecation warning, and removed from docstrings) a few kwargs for sending additional attributes to the underlying MPL commands.  

UPDATE4: I've now updated the docs for these callbacks, added tests, and added a cookbook recipe to show off some of the callbacks.  This PR is ready for full review.

UPDATE5: Removing detailed descriptions from callback docs consistent with suggestions by @ngoldbaum .  Moving the _cb_docstrings.inc file into the callbacks.rst file.
